Dr. K & John,

I associate with John's comment. We are losing sight of the objective which is to change the cost trajectory of healthcare & to provide better coverage by creating a larger insurance risk pool. John's last sentence is important & I hope that healthcare costs will be tracked & it would be useful to track outcomes with metrics that would allow international comparisons.

Medicare for all was a better choice because the costs of that program are low. I have accepted the ACA as a good start. Dr. Emanuel, I think realizes that we can do much better.

It is a mistake is for the pundits, pollsters & predictors like Mr. Silver to politicize the ACA by using it to predict the outcome of the 2014 elections.

It is a foul that learned journalists should try to correct in the media. People are not voting in their economic interests or by the Bush and Obama history of public policy. If they did 2014 would be a landslide for the Dems.

A major journalistic effort should be put into truth telling & current history to help the public understand. It is absolutely irrational for the public to be divided by old tired polarizing issues. Consideration of contraceptive funding by Obamacare by the Supreme Court is a good example of diverting the public away from their economic interests.

Allowing so many polarizing alligators to snap at the public's posterior makes it impossible for the public to realize that the objective is to drain the swamp by voting Democratic.

The President that really deviated from the John Wayne School of Foreign Policy was President Jimmy Carter.  He was in my mind, the best President we ever had.  Based his foreign policy on "Human Rights."  He was too good for us.  (He was a decent character, too.)

It's become conventional wisdom that Americans like leaders who are in favor of dominating or invading sovereign nations, as if it denoted courage. Trouble is, neither political party deviates from this madness. When one does, such as John Kennedy or Bill Bradley, he disappears fast.

We need to grow up. Our infrastructure is falling apart, the oil and armaments industries call the shots, and the rich are trying to drive wages down below poverty levels. Only the people can rise up and change it, and if we're not up to it, we'll continue to live the consumerist airhead lives that we deserve.

I'm also disturbed that some of the harshest words about social safety nets are coming from the places where these securities are needed and utilized.  Timothy Egan had a great column last year about Kentucky's representatives being outspoken critics of supposedly wasteful programs, though that state has a high percentage of food stamp recipients and these politicians presumably reflect constituents' beliefs.  Some people look down their nose on those who appear different, while others pretend their reflection belongs to someone else.

US credibility and power have been diminished in the world over the last decade. Our invasion of Iraq insured that and such a colossal foreign policy blunder will shape how the world views US leadership abilities for years to come.

Our invasion of Iraq was publicly premised on the complete lie that Saddam Hussein had WMD's, was involved in the planning of 9/11 and was an imminent threat to our national security. It also empowered Iranian dominance of the region, left over 100,000 Iraqis dead and legitimized torture as a tool of war. It was a stupid and disgraceful act.

This is our legacy to the world in the early years of the 21st Century. Putin's incursion into Crimea pales in comparison to what we did in Iraq. That's why President Obama needs to walk a very fine line in dealing with the blow up in Ukraine. It's also why he assured those at home and abroad that diplomatic efforts and economic sanctions, not military action are where solutions must be found.

He faces skepticism abroad and Republicans at home who've apparently not learned one lesson from Iraq, demanding he bang the drum loudly and aggressively until he puts Putin in his place. If Donald Rumsfeld is looking for humans dumber than apes, I suggest he look in the mirror and then, at Mitt Romney, John McCain and the rest of his war mongering friends.

I am very grateful to the NYT for publishing this article. The stigma attached to mental illness is still with us, unfortunately. It is a disease that often ends in suicide. I lost my father to suicide. It was not his first attempt, but between the first and the last, he got to see me graduate from high school and then college. He became a grandfather. He had many happy days. The aching sorrow felt by those left behind never completely heals.
During one of two "Out of the Darkness" walks - sponsored by the AFSP (American Foundation for Suicide Prevention http://theovernight.donordrive.com) - to bring resources and awareness to the epidemic of suicide - I was a walker, and met a young man who jumped off the GG bridge and survived. He now shares his story of recovery all over the country and is in the film, "The Bridge". Many on these walks have thought about suicide, made actual attempts or are family and friends of those, like my dad, who were "successful" in carrying them out.
I believe it isn't a matter of choice between spending the money for the Golden Gate Bridge barrier or spending it on mental health education. We need to do it all. There is money to be found (managed) at all levels of government - along with private donations - to make this happen. And if you think this isn't something in which the government should get involved, think about all the soldiers who are taking their own lives after serving our country.

"James C. Eddie, the board president who in 2008 was the sole vote against the net barrier..."  Does this mean that the vote has to be unanimous?  An 18-1 vote doesn't pass?  That is unbelievable.  How does the board function at all if that is the case?

You are misquoting the study in question. It did not study people who "attempted suicide" off the Bridge. Quite obviously, less than 10% of those people were alive even moments later, nevermind decades.

No, it studied people who were talked out of jumping off the Bridge, which is a whole different animal. Unless you can know that those people were serious about jumping, and not just crying for help -- which you cannot possibly know -- you cannot reach the conclusion you are claiming. Furthermore, the study fails to control for the intervention itself -- because that's impossible.

Maybe the mere fact that someone cared enough to talk the person out of jumping changed their attitude about life? Maybe that is actually a positive... that wouldn't occur if the person simply stepped in front of a train, as they do weekly here in Illinois.

It's alarming how willing people are to draw conclusions from data that is obviously junk. You cannot study half a population and reach any meaningful conclusion. Maybe every person who DID jump and die was glad they did? We cannot know. Maybe all of the people who were serious about jumping did, and the rest -- the subjects of this study -- just needed someone to talk to them? We can't know that either.

Think about what a study really says before quoting it, please.
Well of course the barrier will be up for more than one year. How about it saving 2000 lives over 10 years or 4000 over 20. How would that sound?
"We shouldn't spend the money on this problem because we have other problems" is not a convincing argument.

I live a mile away from the bridge and cross it many times each week. I also travel extensively, and am amazed by how many people the world over identify the Golden Gate Bridge as THE symbol of California. Unfortunately, they have two associations: structural magnificence and suicides.

I had to chuckle: $68 million dollars is a drop in the fiscal bucket for an economy the size of the Bay Area - I know of two single-family residences the value of which exceed that amount. It is naive to think that those funds, if unspent, would actually go to a worthy cause with more impact than this one.
I hope the barrier saves lives but it is expensive and that $68 million dollars could do a lot to save more than 200 people a year.

There is a social contract in place that says it is not ok to commit suicide. We are supposed to deal with our discontent somehow. Be it through anti-depressants, shopping for the next iPhone, new partners, or new religion, we are expected to fix our despair or face shame and scorn if we do not.

I understand that putting up a barrier will save lives. I understand that some people are impulsive. I also know that a barrier is merely a Band Aid to hide the ill-effects of the materialistic society we live in. I live near this bridge and cross it often, either by car or foot. There are call boxes and signs along the bridge encouraging people to seek assistance. But why don't we take the next step? Why doesn't the GG Bridge District allot some of its substantial revenues toward creative and smart thinking beyond a stainless steel net?

Lastly, it feels odd to live in a country where there is so much debate and concern about loss of life, while we support and pay for a government that does not seem to care much about killing people all over the globe. From my point of view, this conversation only begins at the Golden Gate Bridge. Poetic!

Uh, not quite.  This Board is hardly the most extreme.  And, by the way, the NLRB did not make this decision, it was made by a Regional Director in Chicago, although it will likely be appealed to the full Board.  No, this decision will have little or no impact on most college athletes.  Major D-1 football and basketball programs -- sure, but probably not much of an impact beyond that.  And the labor board does not decide what taxable income is, Congress and the IRS make those determinations so all those who think college athletes will get their comeuppance because they'll have to pay taxes need to calm down.  Anyone who takes the time to read the decision might actually understand why the Regional Director  reached this conclusion.

The NLRB - currently one of the most extreme in its history - has just rendered every college athlete ineligible to play sports under current NCAA rules, since pay-for-play eliminates their amateur standing. They will also owe the IRS a heap of taxes on their "compensation," which will doubtless come as a shock to the Northwestern players, who have just been declared to have "income" over the national median. This should be fun.

I live in Oakland, and I love the new Bay Bridge, for all the bad press it's had over cost overruns and mechanical defects. Now it's evidently New York's turn to kvetch.

When the Golden Gate and the GW were built, people still recognized that life is short, and (in the midst of a Depression) chose to enjoy it (bridges and all) for what it is. The GW's towers were initially planned to be clad in granite, but the ironwork was left exposed to cut costs, and it remains that way -- recognized as a magnificent span. Why are we so cranky about everything today?

As for the prospect of a $12 toll, that seems to be in line with how much more everything (even housing) costs in NY than it does in the Bay Area. People should stop kvetching and re-learn to love life.

I'm tired of hearing people say that a bus lane is needed for the new bridge.  How many people ride the bus anyway? Its limited and quite frankly, its not very comfortable.  Throw in a train over the new bridge and I would easily pay any reasonable amount of money.

This latest blog posting is great because it reminds me of the kind of feeling that I had when I first read of the Foundation Trilogy by Assimov and was taking an Econ intro class which used Samuelson's book. This was about 50 years ago. I was an engineering student at the time. The neat curves used in these models represent simple but powerful ideas and concepts of human behavior.

In the physical world definitions have a real meaning and physical existence whereas in a social science they have seemed arbitrary, ad hoc, and nebulous. In the case of economics the only tie with reality is that of quantitative data provided by money and transactions.

I'm convinced the only way to discuss the economy is through these simple models. While they may not be completely accurate, they are a very precise way to understand the actions of millions of individuals acting on their own economic circumstances. The proof of the accurateness is in the trend of the projections that can be made from the model.
